natural problem: Find all solutions to the inequality \[\frac{(2x-7)(x-3)}{x} \ge 0.\](Give your answer in interval notation.)
natural solution: Let $f(x)$ be the quantity on the left-hand side. Constructing a sign table, we get \begin{tabular}{c|ccc|c} &$2x-7$ &$x-3$ &$x$ &$f(x)$ \\ \hline$x<0$ &$-$&$-$&$-$&$-$\\ [.1cm]$0<x<3$ &$-$&$-$&$+$&$+$\\ [.1cm]$3<x<\frac{7}{2}$ &$-$&$+$&$+$&$-$\\ [.1cm]$x>\frac{7}{2}$ &$+$&$+$&$+$&$+$\\ [.1cm]\end{tabular}It follows that $f(x) > 0$ when $0 < x < 3$ or $x > \tfrac72.$ Since the inequality is nonstrict, we must include the values of $x$ such that $f(x) = 0,$ which are $x=3$ and $x=\tfrac72.$ Thus, the solution set is \[x \in \boxed{(0, 3] \cup [\tfrac72, \infty)}.\]

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real
assumes h0 : "x \<noteq> 0"
shows  "((2 * x - 7) * (x - 3)) / x \<ge> 0 \<longleftrightarrow> (x > 0 \<and> x \<le> 3) \<or> x \<ge> 7/2"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find all solutions to the inequality \[\frac{(2x-7)(x-3)}{x} \ge 0.\](Give your answer in interval notation.) The final Answer is (0, 3] \cup [\tfrac72, \infty)
 ### Proof
 Let $f(x)$ be the quantity on the left-hand side. Constructing a sign table, we get \begin{tabular}{c|ccc|c} &$2x-7$ &$x-3$ &$x$ &$f(x)$ \\ \hline$x<0$ &$-$&$-$&$-$&$-$\\ [.1cm]$0<x<3$ &$-$&$-$&$+$&$+$\\ [.1cm]$3<x<\frac{7}{2}$ &$-$&$+$&$+$&$-$\\ [.1cm]$x>\frac{7}{2}$ &$+$&$+$&$+$&$+$\\ [.1cm]\end{tabular}It follows that $f(x) > 0$ when $0 < x < 3$ or $x > \tfrac72.$ Since the inequality is nonstrict, we must include the values of $x$ such that $f(x) = 0,$ which are $x=3$ and $x=\tfrac72.$ Thus, the solution set is \[x \in \boxed{(0, 3] \cup [\tfrac72, \infty)}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: real
assumes h0 : "x \<noteq> 0"
shows  "((2 * x - 7) * (x - 3)) / x \<ge> 0 \<longleftrightarrow> (x > 0 \<and> x \<le> 3) \<or> x \<ge> 7/2"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Determine for which values of $x$ is the expression $\frac{(2x - 7)(x - 3)}{x}$ greater than or equal to zero, given that $x$ is not equal to zero. The solution is $x > 0$ and $x \leq 3$, or $x \geq \frac{7}{2}$.

shows  "x \<in> {0 <.. 3} \<union> {7/2 <..}"
